title: Top House attorney says Donald Trump could be impeached for lying to the public and obstruction
text:
The top lawyer for the House of Representatives told a federal judge Tuesday that the Democratic impeachment effort may extend well beyond the Ukraine scandal.

House General Counsel Doug Letter made the statements to Judge Beryl Howell, as House Democrats seek to claw documents from the Justice Department that were the foundation of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's inquiry.

He said the president need not have committed a crime to be impeached – then indicated the House was considering matters beyond the Ukraine matter that has lit a fire under House impeachment efforts.

'Another possible impeachment count is obstruction of Congress,' said Letter. That was an area of potential criminal law outlined by Mueller in his report. Mueller included 10 potentially obstructive acts, without reaching a decision on whether or not Trump should be prosecuted.

A House Democratic impeachment effort could go beyond Ukraine, the top House lawyer said in court Tuesday

The judge asked Letter if the president could be impeached for lying to the American public. 'I believe so, yes,' he replied, CNN reported.

'I can't emphasize enough, it's not just Ukraine,' he told Judge Howell, a Barack Obama nominee who oversaw the grand jury during the Mueller probe.

It is ultimately up to House Democrats, led by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, to decide on what grounds, if any, to vote articles of impeachment. The Constitutional provides few guardrails, stating that Congress may impeach a president for 'high crimes and misdemeanors.'

'The House of Representatives ... shall have the sole Power of Impeachment,' the Constitution states in Article I, Section II.

Pelosi has cautioned lawmakers to keep impeachment narrowly focused on the Ukraine matter, where a whistle-blower alleges Trump abused power by asking the president of Ukraine to investigate political opponent Joe Biden and his son's company.

Democrats are seeking memos known as 302s summarizing interviews with officials as part of the Russia probe

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has urged keeping the impeachment effort narrowly tailored

Democrats want details on former White House Counsel Don McGahn's interviews, which featured in Mueller's obstruction section

Top House lawyer Douglas Letter was a senior Justice Department official in 2018

The speaker was also late to jump aboard the impeachment train, having cautioned earlier the effort was likely to fail in the Senate.

She told ABC's George Stephanopoulos: 'Let's not take it too far afield. That's a matter of the committee to pursue. But for now, just stay focused on what the president did and how does that support our national security, honor his oath of office, and not undermine our electoral integrity.’

She has not specifically ruled out going in other directions, however, and has not scheduled a formal House vote on an impeachment inquiry, which the White House is now demanding she do.

Democrats continue to seek FBI 302s, the agent notes on interviews conducted for Mueller's probe. The are particularly interested in interviews with former White House Counsel Don McGahn, who is quoted repeatedly in the Mueller report describing efforts by Trump to fire Mueller and get him to later claim there was no such effort to remove the special counsel.

Democrats have blasted the administration for stonewalling a range of their investigatory efforts. On Tuesday the Justice Department said it would provide 33 FBI memos, but only in redacted form.
description: House General Counsel Doug Letter told a federal judge Democratic impeachment efforts could be go beyond Ukraine, and that Trump could even be impeached for lying to the public.
authors: Deputy U.S. Political Editor For Dailymail.Com
